p: Climate change threatens to significantly impact the survival and persistence of fish, particularly for species living close to their thermal tolerance limits and are thus prone to be harmed by small changes in environmental temperatures [ 21– 27]. In this sense, adaptation of these species to their current environmental conditions may provide important clues as to how they might endure future environmental changes. Besides rising temperatures, acidification can also affect freshwater biota [ 28]. Recently, considerable attention has been given to ocean acidification and this process is widely known to affect the physiology and behavior of many marine species (e.g. [ 29– 34]), ranging from changes in olfactory systems [ 29], neurotransmitter malfunctions [ 35] and skeletal deformities [ 36, 37]. Unlike ocean acidification which is caused by elevated atmospheric CO 2 concentrations, lake and river acidification is mainly driven by acid rain [ 38]. However, freshwater acidification is also likely to be affected by future increases in CO 2 levels [ 39]. To date, few studies have examined the effects of increasing CO 2 and acidification, as mediated by climate change, on freshwater fish [ 40].
